articles.headline: Delay, Deny and Deflect: How Facebook’s Leaders Fought Through Crisis
articles.snippet: Russian meddling, data sharing, hate speech — the social network faced one scandal after another. This is how Mark Zuckerberg and Sheryl Sandberg responded.
articles.abstract: Russian meddling, data sharing, hate speech — the social network faced one scandal after another. This is how Mark Zuckerberg and Sheryl Sandberg responded.
articles.byline: By Sheera Frenkel, Nicholas Confessore, Cecilia Kang, Matthew Rosenberg and Jack Nicas

articles.headline: California Utility Customers May Be on Hook for Billions in Wildfire Damage
articles.snippet: Pacific Gas and Electric Company’s stock has been cut almost in half since last week as investors assess the potential payout if its equipment is found to blame.
articles.abstract: Pacific Gas and Electric Company’s stock has been cut almost in half since last week as investors assess the potential payout if its equipment is found to blame.
articles.lead_paragraph: As wildfires ravage large swaths of California for a second year, one of the state’s biggest utilities has declared that it faces billions of dollars in potential liability — far more than its insurance would cover.
articles.byline: By Ivan Penn and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: In Florida Recount, Sloppy Signatures Placed Thousands of Ballots in Limbo
articles.snippet: Thousands of ballots have been rejected in Florida because voters’ signatures don’t match what’s on file. Democrats are arguing that’s disenfranchisement.
articles.abstract: Thousands of ballots have been rejected in Florida because voters’ signatures don’t match what’s on file. Democrats are arguing that’s disenfranchisement.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIVIERA BEACH, Fla. — The nuns at Zina Rodriguez’s Catholic school in the Bronx thwacked her knuckles to punish sloppy handwriting, so she was shocked when her mail-in ballot in Florida was rejected because her signature did not match the one on record with elections officials.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush, Audra D. S. Burch and Frances Robles

articles.headline: Sherrod Brown: Rumpled, Unvarnished and Just Maybe a Candidate for President
articles.snippet: The Ohio senator has solved the mystery of how to win as a Democrat in a right-leaning Midwestern state. Is that a viable path to success in 2020?
articles.abstract: The Ohio senator has solved the mystery of how to win as a Democrat in a right-leaning Midwestern state. Is that a viable path to success in 2020?
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — One after another, the Democratic candidates in Ohio fell.

articles.headline: Scandals Catch Up to Private Chinese Hospitals, After Fortunes Are Made
articles.snippet: The Putian network of 8,000 facilities, which expanded rapidly with little government oversight, is facing national outrage and scrutiny over a death and fraud allegations.
articles.abstract: The Putian network of 8,000 facilities, which expanded rapidly with little government oversight, is facing national outrage and scrutiny over a death and fraud allegations.
articles.lead_paragraph: PUTIAN, China — Chen Deliang, wearing an orange tunic, a gold watch and fluffy bedroom slippers decorated with snowflakes and the word “Love,” stood proudly in the 130,000-square-foot temple he had built. He had filled it with pagodas, Buddhas and a towering statue of a local goddess. There were several wings, with bedrooms and an office where he practiced calligraphy.

articles.headline: What to Know About Getting a Flu Shot This Year, No Matter Who’s Paying
articles.snippet: Flu season is here, and there are at least six types of vaccine to choose from. It’s worth studying the options to determine which is likely to protect you the most.
articles.abstract: Flu season is here, and there are at least six types of vaccine to choose from. It’s worth studying the options to determine which is likely to protect you the most.
articles.lead_paragraph: When I went to a pharmacy in Brooklyn to get a flu shot last year, I was presented with a choice: one vaccine with three different strains of the flu virus for about $30 or, for just $10 more, four strains. It sounded vaguely like a late-night television infomercial.

articles.headline: Saudis Shift Account of Khashoggi Killing Again, as 5 Agents Face Death Penalty
articles.snippet: The kingdom’s prosecutor acknowledged that Saudi agents dismembered the dissident, but said the killing was not premeditated. Five agents face the death penalty.
articles.abstract: The kingdom’s prosecutor acknowledged that Saudi agents dismembered the dissident, but said the killing was not premeditated. Five agents face the death penalty.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Saudi Arabia threatened five of its agents with the death penalty on Thursday for killing the dissident Jamal Khashoggi, as the kingdom changed its story, again, about how the crime was committed and continued to try to distance its de facto ruler, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, from any responsibility.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: What Tesla’s ‘Delivery Logistics Hell’ Is Like for Model 3 Buyers
articles.snippet: So close to getting their cars, some customers have encountered delays, mix-ups or quality problems as Elon Musk’s operation tries to work out kinks.
articles.abstract: So close to getting their cars, some customers have encountered delays, mix-ups or quality problems as Elon Musk’s operation tries to work out kinks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Elon Musk has described Tesla’s troubles in getting cars to customers as “delivery logistics hell.”
